msgs.text: LAYERS Maintaining a solid, secure and reliable network on Bitcoin Layer 1 means that people can safely innovate on additional layers built on top of Bitcoin. These additional layers are home to many different types of innovations. It is impossible to predict exactly what will be built in the future, but if what's been done so far is any indication, we can expect some tremendous things to come. LIGHTNING NETWORK The Lightning Network is a Bitcoin Layer 2 solution that helps Bitcoin scale and enables low fee, extremely fast (and as I've witnessed, seemingly instantaneous) transactions. Lightning was made possible after Bitcoin's SegWit upgrade. The easiest way to understand how Lighting works is comparing it to opening a tab at a bar. You buy drinks one at a time and eventually settle your transactions at the end of the night. Similarly, with lightning, you can transact a bunch of times and settle later. The Lightning Network is similar to a ‚Äúdata link‚Äù layer in that it allows communication between nodes for final settlement. The clearest difference between the Lightning Network and Fedwire though is that you need to be a bank to participate in the Fedwire system, whereas basically anyone can open a Lightning channel, without permission required. Fedwire communicates between banks, Lightning communicates between anybody that wants a channel. It is important to note that two transacting lightning channel balances can adjust in milliseconds and do not require immediate settlement on the base layer. The transactions made in a Lightning channel do not exist on-chain, but the final balance of the channel is eventually broadcasted on-chain when a channel is closed.

Lightning actually processes transactions one million times more energy efficient than Visa, and it is open to the billions in the world without access to a bank account. This will enable many people around the world to hurdle banks and jump right into Bitcoin. Andreas prophesizes that kids born today wont have bank accounts (or driver's licenses for that matter); find this quoted here: https://discord.com/channels/874318808423219280/874344285623955516/874344376862642227. To look at it more simply, using the Lightning Network is like opening a bar tab. Transactions happen over and over again on the Lightning Network and eventually get settled at the base layer, like at the end of the night when you pay your bar tab. Another great thing about the Lightning Network is that it is built on top of the Bitcoin's base layer meaning it has all properties of the base layer (decentralization, high security, immutability, etc.). Feel free to mention the Lightning Network to anyone who claims that Bitcoin's transaction speeds are too slow- this is a myth! PRIVACY Additionally, transacting with Lightning is very private. Lightning transactions are not broadcast on the Blockchain. The sender and receiver are the only two parties who are aware of the lighting transaction that they are making, and in most cases, the receiver doesn't even know who the sender is because the routing among lightning channels is with encrypted data.

Transactions per second: ‚Ä¢ Visa: 1,700 ‚Ä¢ MasterCard: 5,000 Bitcoin on Lightning: 25,000,000+ (25,000+ nodes * 1,000 tps (transactions/sec) How to achieve 1,000 tps: https://bottlepay.com/blog/bitcoin-lightning-benchmarking-performance/ LIGHTNING WALLETS There are many (free) lightning wallet apps that you can get on your phone to transact with small amounts of Bitcoin with little to no fees. When using lightning, if one of the parties of the transaction is dishonest and tried to steal money, then the other party can broadcast the transaction to the Bitcoin blockchain and reclaim the funds. The Blockchain, and Bitcoin's proof-of-work consensus mechanism, is therefore used as a dispute resolution service. When both parties are honest, the nuanced, inefficiencies, and scalability constraints of the proof-of-work process can be avoided.

Lightning requires the receiver of the transaction to be online and interact with the sender. This is why it is important to always leave your lightning node online. This is not the case with on-chain transactions.
Lightning also required users to monitor and manage their channels, to ensure they have sufficient liquidity and prevent theft from their channels.

BOLT 12 BOLT payments - Offers is a draft specification (called a "BOLT") for Lightning wallets and nodes, with experimental support already in c-lightning. You scan a QR code, your wallet prompts you to pay it, just like BOLT11 invoices today (the QR code labelled BOLT11 Invoice). But it could also offer to send you money, like for an ATM. And unlike invoices, you can (and should!) reuse them: a static image on your web page, a QR code on your billboard. The BOLT 12 offer can be used by as many people as want to: the BOLT 11 invoice can only be used once, and is insecure if someone else tries to reuse it! SWAPS How do lighting swaps work? ‚óè Person A generates a preimage. ‚óè Person A gives Person B a hash of this preimage. ‚óè Person B creates a hold invoice with this hash, and sends it to Person A. ‚óè Person B funds an on chain Hash time lock contract (HTLC) - if Person A provides the preimage, they get the bitcoin. if 1 day passes, Person B does. ‚óè Person A uses the preimage to claim the HTLC. ‚óè Person B sees this and claims the hold invoice using the preimage on the transaction. Here's an image of one of the more "complicated" swaps A -> B (on chain) B -> A (off chain) So if one is completed the other can be completed too. You can claim the btc on lightning, and B would keep the btc sent on chain? - In total you did not lose or gain sats, but where they are (on -> off chain) changed. A Lightning Network implementation is a software program for
running a node on the Lightning Network. The name implementation stems from the
fact that a given Lightning implementation software is indeed an implementation
of the previously mentioned BOLT specifications. But as long as the software running
your node adheres to the BOLT specifications, you are free to use whatever code
you will. 

There have been three much-used implementations on the Lightning
Network. √âclair by Acinq, c-lightning by Blockstream, and LND by Lightning Labs. The
most favorable implementation for your node depends on the use case and
preferences.
Lightning Dev Kit (LDK) recently launched an implementation focusing on being
easy to integrate into existing (or new) Bitcoin wallets.
